title: Visual Studio Code Setup for FRC

sections.title: Introduction to VS Code for FRC
sections.content:
Visual Studio Code (VS Code) is the recommended integrated development environment (IDE) for FRC programming. When installed with WPILib, it comes pre-configured with the WPILib extension, making it the easiest way to develop FRC robot code. VS Code provides code editing, building, deploying, and debugging capabilities all in one place.

Learn more: WPILib Documentation: VS Code Overview

sections.title: Installing Visual Studio Code
sections.content:
VS Code is typically installed automatically when you install WPILib. However, if you need to install it separately or update it:

Download: Visit code.visualstudio.com and download the installer for your operating system.

Installation: Run the installer and follow the prompts. On Windows, you can choose to add VS Code to your PATH for command-line access.

First Launch: When you first open VS Code, it will guide you through initial setup. You can customize settings or use defaults.

sections.title: WPILib Extension Installation
sections.content:
The WPILib extension adds FRC-specific features to VS Code, including project creation, code deployment, and robot management tools.

Automatic Installation: If VS Code was installed with WPILib, the extension should already be installed.

Manual Installation:
1. Open VS Code
2. Click the Extensions icon in the sidebar (or press Ctrl+Shift+X)
3. Search for 'WPILib'
4. Click 'Install' on the 'WPILib for VS Code' extension
5. Wait for installation to complete
6. Reload VS Code if prompted

Verifying Installation: After installation, you should see WPILib commands available in the Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P). Type 'WPILib' to see available commands.

sections.title: WPILib Extension Features
sections.subtitle: The extension provides:
items: Create new WPILib projects from templates
Build and deploy robot code with keyboard shortcuts
Manage vendor dependencies (CTRE, REV, etc.)
Code IntelliSense and autocomplete for WPILib classes
Integrated terminal with Gradle commands
Robot code management and configuration
Team number configuration
Project structure navigation

sections.title: VS Code Workspace Setup
sections.content:
A workspace in VS Code is a folder containing your project files. Setting up workspaces properly helps organize your development environment.

Opening a Project:
1. Open VS Code
2. Go to File → Open Folder (or Ctrl+K Ctrl+O)
3. Navigate to your FRC project folder
4. Click 'Select Folder'

Workspace Features: Once a folder is open, VS Code treats it as a workspace. The Explorer sidebar shows your project files, and the WPILib extension recognizes it as an FRC project.

Multi-Root Workspaces: For teams with multiple projects, you can create a multi-root workspace by going to File → Add Folder to Workspace. This lets you work with multiple projects simultaneously.

sections.title: Command Palette and WPILib Commands
sections.content:
The Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P or Cmd+Shift+P on Mac) is a powerful way to access VS Code features and WPILib commands.

Accessing Commands: Press Ctrl+Shift+P and start typing. VS Code will filter commands as you type.

Key WPILib Commands:
- WPILib: Create a new project - Create a new robot project
- WPILib: Build Robot Code - Compile your project
- WPILib: Deploy Robot Code - Upload code to robot
- WPILib: Manage Vendor Libraries - Add/remove vendor dependencies
- WPILib: Set Team Number - Configure team number
- WPILib: Manage Robot Code - Robot code management tools

Learn more: WPILib Documentation: Managing Vendor Libraries

sections.title: Integrated Terminal
sections.content:
VS Code includes an integrated terminal that lets you run command-line tools without leaving the editor. This is useful for running Gradle commands directly.

Opening Terminal:
- Press Ctrl+` (backtick) to toggle the terminal
- Or go to Terminal → New Terminal

Using Gradle: In the terminal, you can run Gradle commands:
- ./gradlew build - Build the project
- ./gradlew deploy - Deploy to robot
- ./gradlew clean - Clean build artifacts
- ./gradlew tasks - List available tasks

Note: On Windows, use gradlew.bat instead of ./gradlew.

sections.title: Code Navigation and IntelliSense
sections.content:
VS Code provides powerful code navigation and autocomplete features that make writing code faster and easier.

IntelliSense: As you type, VS Code suggests completions for classes, methods, and variables. Press Ctrl+Space to manually trigger suggestions.

Go to Definition: Right-click on a class or method name and select 'Go to Definition' (or press F12) to see where it's defined.

Find References: Right-click and select 'Find All References' (or Shift+F12) to see where a symbol is used.

Symbol Navigation: Press Ctrl+Shift+O to see all symbols in the current file. Press Ctrl+T to search for symbols across the project.

sections.title: Build Tasks
sections.content:
Build tasks let you run common operations like building or deploying with keyboard shortcuts. The WPILib extension sets up these tasks automatically.

Running Tasks:
1. Press Ctrl+Shift+B to run the default build task
2. Or go to Terminal → Run Task and select a task

Available Tasks:
- WPILib: Build Robot Code - Compiles your project
- WPILib: Deploy Robot Code - Deploys to robot
- WPILib: Clean Build - Removes build artifacts

Configuring Tasks: Tasks are defined in .vscode/tasks.json. The WPILib extension creates this file automatically, but you can customize it if needed.

sections.title: Example tasks.json Structure
Debugging Setup
sections.content:
VS Code includes a debugger that can help you troubleshoot your robot code. While debugging robot code on the roboRIO is limited, you can debug simulation code effectively.

Debug Configuration: Debug configurations are stored in .vscode/launch.json. The WPILib extension may create basic configurations, but you can add more for simulation debugging.

Using the Debugger:
1. Set breakpoints by clicking in the gutter next to line numbers
2. Press F5 to start debugging
3. Use the Debug toolbar to step through code
4. View variables in the Debug sidebar

Note: Debugging on the actual robot requires special setup and is typically only used for simulation.

sections.title: Code Formatting
sections.content:
Consistent code formatting makes your code easier to read and maintain. VS Code can automatically format your Java code.

Formatting Options:
- Format Document: Press Shift+Alt+F (Windows/Linux) or Shift+Option+F (Mac) to format the entire file
- Format Selection: Select text and press Ctrl+K Ctrl+F to format just the selection

Auto-Format on Save: You can configure VS Code to format code automatically when you save:
1. Open Settings (Ctrl+,)
2. Search for 'format on save'
3. Enable 'Editor: Format On Save'

Java Formatter: VS Code uses the built-in Java formatter. For more control, you can install the 'Language Support for Java' extension.

sections.title: Recommended VS Code Extensions
sections.subtitle: Useful extensions for FRC development:
items: WPILib for VS Code: Essential for FRC development (already installed)
Language Support for Java: Enhanced Java language support and IntelliSense
GitLens: Enhanced Git integration and code history
Error Lens: Inline error and warning messages
Code Spell Checker: Catches spelling mistakes in comments and strings
Better Comments: Highlights important comments

sections.title: Git Integration
sections.content:
VS Code has built-in Git support for version control. This is essential for team collaboration and tracking code changes.

Initializing Git: If your project doesn't have Git initialized, VS Code will prompt you. Click 'Initialize Repository' to create a new Git repository.

Viewing Changes: The Source Control sidebar (Git icon) shows modified files. Click files to see diffs.

Committing Changes:
1. Stage files by clicking the '+' icon
2. Enter a commit message
3. Click the checkmark to commit

Branching: Use the branch selector at the bottom of VS Code to create and switch branches.

Learn more: WPILib Documentation: Version Control

sections.title: Workspace Settings
sections.content:
VS Code settings can be configured globally (for all projects) or per-workspace (for a specific project). Workspace settings are stored in .vscode/settings.json.

Common Settings:
- Java formatting preferences
- File encoding (should be UTF-8)
- Tab size and indentation
- Exclude patterns for file search

Accessing Settings: Press Ctrl+, to open Settings. Use the Workspace tab to configure project-specific settings.

sections.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
sections.content:
Learning keyboard shortcuts makes development faster. Here are essential shortcuts for FRC development:

General:
- Ctrl+Shift+P - Command Palette
- Ctrl+` - Toggle Terminal
- Ctrl+B - Toggle Sidebar

Editing:
- Ctrl+Space - Trigger IntelliSense
- Shift+Alt+F - Format Document
- Ctrl+/ - Toggle Line Comment
- Ctrl+D - Select Next Occurrence

Navigation:
- Ctrl+P - Quick Open File
- Ctrl+Shift+O - Go to Symbol in File
- F12 - Go to Definition
- Ctrl+T - Go to Symbol in Workspace

Build/Deploy:
- Ctrl+Shift+B - Build
- Ctrl+F5 - Deploy (WPILib extension)

sections.title: VS Code Best Practices
sections.subtitle: For efficient FRC development:
items: Use the Command Palette for WPILib commands
Enable format on save for consistent code style
Use keyboard shortcuts to speed up workflow
Keep the integrated terminal open for Gradle commands
Use Git for version control
Install recommended extensions for better experience
Customize settings to match your preferences
Use multi-root workspaces for multiple projects
Learn and use code navigation features (Go to Definition, Find References)
